ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to use SolidWorks to make parts, assemblies, motion studies, and simulation studies. I also learned a brief amount of MATLAB.
Good
I gained a very good understanding of Solidworks and design considerations.
Solidworks, design
I learned the basics of CAD and analysis of models.
I gained a lot of experience with Solidworks and MATLAB through this course, in addition to a bit about mechanical/machine deign.
I learned how to use SolidWorks to create complex parts and assemblies, animations, and more advanced analysis such as FEA and flow simulations.
Learned so many great CAD skills!!! Very useful and fun class.
We learned how to CAD different mechanisms in Solidworks and how to analyze them with FEA and fluid simulations.
How to use Solidworks and a bit of Matlab
Very good knowledge of CAD tools and FEA
I learned how to use Solid works for design and analysis.
I learned the basics of computer design in Solidworks
Learned SolidWorks and some Matlab
I learned about 3D modeling techniques and how to analyze components inside of solidworks and how to create motion studies
You learn how to use SolidWorks
I learned a lot more about SolidWorks and the intricacies of the features it offers. I was also introduced to MatLab which Ill most likely use in the future at some point.
Learned fundamental Solidworks skills that can be used for basic projects in a variety of fields
I learned fundamental CAD skills in Solidworks as well as best practices for using CAD in an industry setting.
Amazing course! Would 10/10 recommend.
Learned how to perform CAD modeling with solidworks. Learned Matlab. Learned best with the Mastery Based Learning (MBL) model. Learned the importance of inclusionary design when building things.
A lot better understanding of CAD as well as a ton of practical knowledge about design and industry especially.
Utilizing SolidWorks (assemblies, finite element analysis, simulations, etc.), MatLab, and drawing in perspective.
I learned various features of the Solidworks software as well as a deeper understanding for how engineering design works.
I became much more confident with SolidWorks.

Although I had some CAD experience, I really appreciated this class because you're able to learn a bunch of small tips that just make you so much more efficient at modeling. You also get in depth about motion studies and analysis within Solidworks, which we didn't really learn in other courses, even in MENG 185-- at least when I had it.
I improved my CAD skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course has no real deadlines. This can be a strength or weakness depending on the person. I enjoyed the fact that there were no deadlines because I received no penalties for late work. However, this can make it easy for students to drastically fall behind.
Good

Ronald Adrezin is fantastic.
We should do more required Solidworks tutorials in this class (more assignments that are just doing Solidworks tutorials). 
The projects were generally interesting. 
Project expectations were flexible, which made the class low-stress but also allowed us to spend a lot of time on certain projects if we wanted.

The class allows you to focus on what u want to learn. You can decide how in depth you want to learn each thing. All of the projects teach useful skills in CAD and build on each other but allow you to direct each skill how you want.

Strengths: Really interesting content and a great professor, very lenient grading/deadlines, fun projects, etc. Weaknesses: At times, the class didn't feel very organized and it wasn't very clear what was going on during lecture, but definitely a fun class. The loose deadlines were also very nice throughout the semester, but did make it hard to stay on top of my work.

Strengths: I am a huge fan of the mastery-based learning system applied in this course. On any assignment, as long as you can demonstrate mastery of the skill that the assignment is about, you will get full credit, regardless of when you submit it. SolidWorks is also a fantastic skill to have for a mechanical engineer applying for internships or jobs. 
Weaknesses: I would have loved to get into SolidWorks's simulation capabilities a little bit more.
Sometimes having free work days in class made it so many people didnt show up very often. But final presentations were a strength, as well as the soft deadlines.

I think the structure of this class was very well-designed. I liked that the assignments were all due at the end of the semester because that meant I never felt rushed to just submit a subpar assignment and could wait until I had a less busy week to take my time and make my design more complex.

The biggest strength is Prof A. He is supper funny and overall, an amazing professor, always willing to help and support his students. He makes sure the content is engaging for mechE and non-mechE majors alike
Good assignments, fair grading, still learned a lot

The structure of the course was good, the content was taught in lecture and then time was given for the assignment that put the new knowledge into practice. The professor was available and knowledgeable of the CAD package and really cared about the student's learning.
The assignments are really helpful in learning how to use the different tools that Solidworks has to offer
It was great. Low workload and learned a lot.
I liked this class a lot. I did it mostly asynchronous, and learned a lot. Professor Adrezin gives good feedback and helps you learn a lot. Assignments were reasonable and fun.

Strengths: flexible deadlines for assignments, great professor and helpful TFs
Weaknesses: N/A
I think just a greater volume of projects would help me to further refine my skills, and more help choosing/creating a plan for a final project.
Dr. A was great, and overall the class was very effective at teaching CAD skills. My only criticism of the course is that the way that assignments and due dates overlapped was sometimes confusing.
Amazing course! Would 10/10 recommend.

The Mastery Based Learning (MBL) is an amazing model that should be adopted by every class at Yale. The professor is amazing. I didn't have to stress so much abut my grade and getting it completely right on the first try because I knew Professor Adrezin would tell me what I could do to make it better/give me insight into aspects I hadn't thought about. Could actually learn and stick with a piece instead of just moving on immediately from thing to thing. He was also clearly passionate about the topic and its real life applications, specifically in relation to accommodations for people with disabilities. He never wants access to be a barrier for anyone. Also tells fun stories.
Mastery Based Learning was a really good aspect of the class that made me want to learn the material and do it well.
Not a lot of direct teaching a lot of the learning is done on your own. I would have liked some more specific solidworks teaching there are some concepts in solidworks that we just never covered.

The course was well-balanced between covering new material and discussing assignments and project ideas with the instructors. After the mid-semester feedback, the lecture/tutorial content was more student driven in that one volunteer would share their screen alongside the professor as everyone else followed along. I found this format really helpful and think that it should continue. I would also suggest that the computers in the classroom should have cameras for Zoom instruction, but this is more of a technical or administrative issue.

I enjoyed the mastery-based approach given that engineering design should be focused on continuous improvement rather than getting it right the first time. One of the weaknesses of the class was that there was no engineering design book that one could look for to construct advanced mechanisms.
Doc A is great. He makes the class enjoyable and is a very patient and understanding instructor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any student, even if they're not interested in mechanical engineering at all. This course teaches you how to make 3D models and the final project permits you to make whatever you want.
Good
Yes, this course is essential for engineering students.
Solidworks is very useful.
Yes, anyone interested in CAD or modeling or engineering or architecture. It is a great course for an intro into cad fro anyone.
Yes. I think that CAD modeling is a useful skill, especially for engineers, and Prof. Adrezin is a ton of friend.

Yes. This is probably the chillest MENG class out there, and Doc A is a very fun professor. This class does require a good deal of self-management, though, to make sure that you don't procrastinate all of the mastery-based assignments to the end of the year.

This class was a great experience to learn and get better at CAD, no matter the starting skill level. It never feels like too much work, because if you have a busy week you can always submit the assignment later without any penalty to your grade. This was a great way to learn more about the best practices in CAD and to get more experience in it.
Yes, definitely! It was simply a great course. All grades were also based on effort and completion so you knew how you were doing throughout the semester, and you could resubmit work for full credit.
YES, to anyone that is looking to be a competent engineer or architect
Yes, this course was one of my favorites this semester. If you have any interest in design and analysis or CAD I would highly recommend.
Yes - it is a good class in order to improve your Solidworks skills
Yes one of the best classes I've taken
Yes. He grades mostly on participation, and is very kind and entertaining. I didnt go to class much, but still feel like I learned a ton.
Yes absolutely! Great class and Doc A is funny.
Yes! Great course for anyone interested in learning SolidWorks.
Yes. CAD is a skill that I think most people should acquire.

I would definitely recommend this class if you are interested in learning how to use Solidworks. If you already know Solidworks or some other CAD package, as I did going into the course, there is still definitely a lot to learn about how to use certain tools and industry best practices.
Amazing course! Would 10/10 recommend.

Yes. One of the best classes at Yale. The professor really cares about his students and you learning. He is also extremely passionate about the topic and gives insight into real life applications. Mastery Based Learning (MBL) is an amazing model that all classes should adopt.
Highly! I think every Mechanical engineer or engineer in general should take this course.

This is a good engineering course to take, even if you are not specifically in mechanical engineering. The material is useful for articulating design ideas, and the instructors were very helpful and understanding.

Yes! This course is amazing for understanding engineering design from the ground up. Moreover, as an elective, this course was extremely refreshing as the workload is manageable and allows students to design to their heart's content.

Yes! All engineering courses should be taught like this course. So much focus on learning skills as opposed to cramming information for tests and performance in assessments. You will learn SolidWorks well and enjoy doing it because the course is taught in such a relaxed manner.
Yes if you want to learn more about CAD. It's a great intro course.
It is a great class to have some fun designing and casually learning and hearing jokes from a witty professor.
